Bay Street, east side, between Nautilus Street and New Lane, showing St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.

View 1: May 26, 1926
View 2: July 11, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, east side, between Nautilus Street and New Lane, showing St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.

View 1: May 26, 1926
View 2: July 11, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street, shown is the telegraph building of the United States Quarantine Station, near the shore of the Upper New York Bay.

July 19, 1926  Views 1, 2

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street, shown is the telegraph building of the United States Quarantine Station, near the shore of the Upper New York Bay.

July 19, 1926  Views 1, 2

P. L. Sperr

(1) and (2)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown are buildings of the United States Quarantine Station, as seen from the Upper New York Bay. The house on the left is the Doctor's Residence, about 100 years old.
P. L. Sperr  July 19, 1926
(3)
The Quarantine Station, seen from Cliff Street.
Viewing north.
April 29, 1931
P. L. Sperr

(1) and (2)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown are buildings of the United States Quarantine Station, as seen from the Upper New York Bay. The house on the left is the Doctor's Residence, about 100 years old.
P. L. Sperr  July 19, 1926
(3)
The Quarantine Station, seen from Cliff Street.
Viewing north.
April 29, 1931
P. L. Sperr

(1) and (2)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown are buildings of the United States Quarantine Station, as seen from the Upper New York Bay. The house on the left is the Doctor's Residence, about 100 years old.
P. L. Sperr  July 19, 1926
(3)
The Quarantine Station, seen from Cliff Street.
Viewing north.
April 29, 1931
P. L. Sperr

1370 Bay Street, between Evelyn Place and Hope Avenue. The Robinson map of 1898 shows it to have been the home of John Larkin.

April 30, 1931

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, east side, between Nautilus Street and New Lane, showing St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The views are toward Bay Street.

March 25, 1934
Views 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, east side, between Nautilus Street and New Lane, showing St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The views are toward Bay Street.

March 25, 1934
Views 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

Bay Street, east side, between Nautilus Street and New Lane, showing St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The views are toward Bay Street.

March 25, 1934
Views 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown is the U. S. Quarantine Station as seen from the Upper New York Bay. The old building on the left is the Western Union telegraph office and on the right is the Doctor's Residence,about 100 years old. Visible too, is the steeple of St. Johns P. E.
Church.
August 17, 1934
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The old Western Union telegraph office and newly erected buildings, seen from the interior of the Quarantine.
May 31, 1937
P. L. Sperr

(1)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown is the U. S. Quarantine Station as seen from the Upper New York Bay. The old building on the left is the Western Union telegraph office and on the right is the Doctor's Residence,about 100 years old. Visible too, is the steeple of St. Johns P. E.
Church.
August 17, 1934
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The old Western Union telegraph office and newly erected buildings, seen from the interior of the Quarantine.
May 31, 1937
P. L. Sperr

(1) Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street, showing the driveway into the U.S. Quarantine Station, and ground being broken for a new building. The view is eastward toward The Narrows.

About December 3, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, another view.

About December 3, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street, showing the driveway into the U.S. Quarantine Station, and ground being broken for a new building. The view is eastward toward The Narrows.

(2) The same, another view.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Bay Street, at the N.E. corner of Nautilus Street. Shown is the old Doctor's Residence of the U. S. Quarantine
Station, said to be 100 years old.
September 15, 1935

P. L. Sperr

(2)
A view at a later date, showing the house under
demolition.
September 4, 1936.
